title: Between 1 October 2018 and 30 September 2019, will an armed group from Nigeria engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Nigeria?
preds: I have not seen a list of units departing AFRICOM yet nor have I looked at the French disposition - but these will be my flags and indicators for reaching the standard for yes.

There aren't enough people dead at this point. Using ACLEDData.com, only (only) 569 civilians by  have been killed from January to November by Government forces, and that is without accounting for the killings have been against one group or are organized in the slightest. Unless, there is a massive spike in the next month and 10 days.

Although violence has plagued Nigeria in recent years, it's unlikely that an armed group will engage in a campaign that systematically kills more than 1,000 civilians in the next year. By far, the biggest threat to civilian safety the past few years has been the militant Islamist movement Boko Haram. This group does target civilians through suicide bombings and other attacks, but the group's power has declined after significant efforts on the part of the Nigerian military and other countries in the region. In 2017, the group killed more than 300 people, but nothing suggests that these killings were systematic or in a single campaign. Although the military itself does have high levels of corruption and extrajudicial killings, and other armed groups are active, it is unlikely that any single group would be motivated or able to commit systematic killings on such a large scale.  Sources: https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/nigerias-battle-boko-haram
https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2018/country-chapters/nigeria
Unsolved Problems with boko haram and other extrem-islamistic groups.
